title: faith
comment: A constant outlook of trust towards God, whereby human beings abandon all reliance on their own efforts and put their full confidence in him, his word and his promises.

children.title: faith, nature of
children.comment: Confidence in and commitment to God and Jesus Christ. These attitudes remain sure even though the objects of faith are unseen. True faith is seen in obedient action, love and continuing good works.

children.title: God as the object of faith
Jesus Christ as the object of faith
Faith is personal trust in God
Faith may be mixed with doubt

secondaryrefs.comment: the father of the boy with an evil spirit

children.title: Faith as trust in what is unseen
Faith looks towards an unseen future
True faith is demonstrated in obedience
True faith is demonstrated in good deeds
faith, as basis of salvation
children.comment: Both in the OT and in the NT faith is the only basis of salvation. Faith is the means by which God's grace in Christ, and with him the blessings of salvation, is received. Paul's doctrine of justification by faith emphasises the centrality of faith in the Christian life.

children.title: Salvation by faith in the OT
The faith of Abraham and other individuals

seealsos.comment: Abraham, the father of those righteous by faith

children.title: Salvation by faith in the NT
Salvation is by faith in Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: Being ``lifted up'' is a reference to Jesus Christ's death on the cross
The necessity of outward confession, as evidence of personal faith in Jesus Christ.

children.title: Salvation is for all who believe

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ is the ``end of the law'', in the sense that he brings it to its goal and fulfilment, and accomplishes its intentions.

children.title: Salvation is for those who persevere in their faith
Saving faith shows itself in action
Blessings of salvation received through faith
The gift of the Holy Spirit
faith, necessity of
children.comment: A fundamental duty for all people and the necessary response to God's self-revelation. The only channel through which God's blessings may be received, and the only means by which life may be made meaningful, in relationship with God.

children.title: God's self-revelation leaves no excuse for unbelief
The need for faith in God
The LORD is the only true God
God alone can be trusted absolutely
Faith in God is the basis for peace
Faith is necessary to receive God's blessing
Faith is necessary to avoid God's judgment
Actions not springing from faith are sinful

secondaryrefs.comment: comparison with the Israelites in the wilderness
Jesus Christ's disciples after the resurrection

children.title: faith, and blessings of God
children.comment: Confidence in the ability and willingness of God to act in supernatural power to advance his kingdom, and a commitment, expressed in prayer and action, to being the means by which he does so.

children.title: God's power is released through faith
In the OT, faith in God's power

seealsos.comment: Abraham's faith when promised an heir in his old age
Jonathan's confidence in God's power to defeat the Philistines
David's confidence in God's power to overcome Goliath
Jehoshaphat's faith in God's power to give success against Moab and Ammon
Hezekiah's faith in God when threatened by the Assyrians under Sennacherib
Daniel's faith when in the lions' den

children.title: In the NT, healing in response to faith

primaryrefs.comment: The woman had exercised faith by touching the edge of Jesus Christ's cloak.

seealsos.comment: One of the ten men with leprosy who thanked Jesus Christ
the crippled man at the temple gate
Exceptional faith to meet specific needs is a special spiritual gift.

children.title: The importance of love accompanying faith
faith, origins of
children.comment: Faith is a gift from God himself and is not to be seen as the result of human striving or achievement. Faith is inspired by the word and works of God.

children.title: Faith is a gift from God
Faith following a direct word from God

secondaryrefs.comment: Moses receives God's instructions at the Red Sea
Joshua receives God's instructions concerning Jericho

children.title: Faith comes through hearing God's word preached
Faith comes through a personal encounter with Jesus Christ

seealsos.comment: the miracle at the wedding feast
Jesus Christ heals an official's son.

children.title: Faith based on knowledge of God
Knowledge of God's faithfulness leads to faith
Knowledge of God's achievements leads to faith
faith, growth in
children.comment: Christians are called to have a growing faith, built up by prayer and the encouragement of others, and also through testing.

children.title: faith, testing of
children.comment: The means through which the genuineness of faith is proved and Christian character developed. God promises to help his people during times of testing.

children.title: God allows faith to be tested
Testing proves the genuineness of faith
Examples of God testing faith
children.precomment: Abraham is told to sacrifice Isaac:

secondaryrefs.comment: God tested Israel in the desert
Jesus Christ appears to discourage the Canaanite woman
Jesus Christ delays going to Bethany when Lazarus is ill.

children.title: Means by which faith is tested
God allows Satan to test faith
God's promise of help during testing
God's help through the encouragement of others
Rejoicing at sharing Jesus Christ's suffering
Examples of faith victorious through testing
faith, as a body of beliefs
children.comment: That body of essential truth to which Christians hold. It is revealed by God and is to be passed on by faithful teachers. Believers are urged to remain true to the faith and to contend for it.

children.title: Faith as the truth that Christians believe
The source and transmission of the faith
The faith has been given by God
The faith is passed on by apostles and teachers
Christians must remain true to the faith
The danger of turning from the faith
Christians must contend for the faith
Contending for the faith is a responsibility of leaders

secondaryrefs.comment: overseers, who must be able to teach
Timothy, responsible for the church at Ephesus
